intro: Scilla bifolia var. secunda, commonly known as the lesser squill, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It features slender, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of bell-shaped, blue or purple flowers in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–20 cm and prefers well-drained soil in full sun to partial shade. It is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats and is valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
